Fe-modified biochar microspheres (FeBM) were developed as sustainable catalysts for the microwave-assisted upgrading of Fluid Catalytic Cracking-derived Vacuum Gas Oil (FCC-VGO), both in the presence and absence of decaline as hydrogen donor source. The biochars were synthesized by hydrothermal carbonization of starch at 200 °C for 6 and 12 h, followed by incipient wetness impregnation with 1.8 wt% Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2·6H2O. Structural and surface analyses (FTIR, XPS, Raman, SEM) confirmed the formation of carbonaceous microspheres with homogeneously dispersed Fe species, surface oxidation (Fe-O, SO4 2-), and stability under microwave irradiation. These features enhanced interfacial polarization and amphiphilic balance, facilitating the cleavage of S-C and aromatic CO bonds. Raman spectra confirmed the preservation of carbon domains after Fe incorporation. Under mild conditions (80 °C, 6 min, 800 W), FeBM12 exhibited the best catalytic performance, achieving a 77.03% viscosity reduction (from 444 to 102 mPa·s), increasing saturates to 65.6 wt%, and reducing asphaltenes to 2.2 wt%. Zeta potential measurements (-30.7 mV for FeBM12) and contact angle analysis (60.4°) demonstrated enhanced colloidal stability and surface polarity. These parameters favored catalyst dispersion and oil-catalyst interactions, which are critical for microwave responsiveness and catalytic efficiency. In comparison to conventional systems requiring high temperatures, long reaction times, or pressurized hydrogen, FeBM12 offers a low-cost, low-temperature, and energy-efficient platform for upgrading FCC-derived VGO. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biochar microspheres FCC-VGO Fe-doping Hydrothermal carbonization Microwave-assisted upgrading Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Approximately 80 % of the world’s energy consumption is still derived from fossil fuels, particularly in sectors such as transportation, agriculture, and industry [1]. However, this dependency faces increasing challenges due to the ongoing depletion of conventional oil fields, prompting a shift toward non-conventional sources such as heavy oil, extra-heavy oil, and bitumen. These alternative feedstocks typically exhibit high viscosity, low API gravity (American Petroleum Institute gravity, ranging from 10 to 22.3 degrees), and are rich in macromolecular fractions such as asphaltenes, resins, and aromatics, along with elevated concentrations of sulfur, nitrogen, oxygen, and heavy metals [2,3]. Consequently, international energy projections highlight the growing relevance of heavy crude oil and bitumen as key components of future energy strategies [4,5]. Nevertheless, this transition presents significant challenges for oil producers, who must address issues related to the transportation and refining of these complex feedstocks, as well as the higher costs associated with their extraction and treatment [6]. A wide range of technologies has been developed for the upgrading and extraction of heavy and extra-heavy crude oils, including aquaconversion, fluid catalytic cracking, hydrotreating, microwave heating, steam injection, chemical flooding, and in situ combustion [5–8]. Among these, microwave radiation (MR) has gained increasing attention due to its rapid energy transfer, volumetric heating efficiency, and selective interaction with polar and conductive species at molecular and sub-molecular levels. Unlike conventional thermal methods, which often involve high water consumption, limited efficiency in heterogeneous reservoirs, and viscosity reversibility upon cooling, MR enables localized, controllable heating based on the dielectric properties of the medium [9]. Biochar — a porous, carbon- and oxygen-rich solid produced via pyrolysis, hydrothermal carbonization, or gasification of lignocellulosic or carbohydrate-based feedstocks was employed as a functional support due to its unique physicochemical properties [10,11]. The morphology and porosity of biochars vary significantly depending on the precursor; for example, lignocellulosic biomass typically yields non-spherical particles, while glucose or starch precursors result in spherical structures [12,13]. In this sense, Tran et al. [13] demonstrated the synthesis of both morphologies using glucose and grapefruit peel residues for paracetamol adsorption, obtaining high surface areas and pore volumes (up to 1292 m2/g and 0.704 cm3/g). Both biochars exhibited high adsorption capacities, reaching 286 mg/g for spherical and 147 mg/g for non-spherical samples. Recent advances in microwave-assisted upgrading of heavy crude oil have demonstrated significant improvements in viscosity reduction, sulfur removal, and asphaltene conversion using nanocatalysts and electromagnetic heating. Li et al. [14] were among the first to investigate the effect of particle size on carbon-based catalyst performance. They evaluated catalysts with particle sizes of 21.0 nm (A), 70.0–80.0 nm (B), 5.8–7.1 μm (C), and 40.0–51.5 μm (D). Catalyst A exhibited the best performance, achieving over 96 % viscosity reduction, followed by B (83 %), C (20 %), and D (5 %). However, all catalysts experienced viscosity rebound after 20 days, indicating limited long-term stability. Subsequently, Taheri et al. [15,16] conducted comprehensive studies showing that microwave treatment (up to 14 min) increased C1-C20 fractions to 13.5 wt %, reduced asphaltenes from 12.75 to 9.13 %, and cut resins by 55 %, while comparing Fe, TiO2, and activated carbon (CA). Gharibshahi et al. [17] evaluated Fe3O4, Fe3O4−MWCNT, and Fe3O4 NiO catalysts under microwave irradiation for 4, 8, and 12 mins. The Fe3O4−MWCNT catalyst (0.5 wt. % Fe, 400 W, 8 min) achieved a 12 % viscosity reduction, a 5.6 % increase in API gravity, and a 16.6 % decrease in sulfur content. In a similar approach, Vakhin et al. [18] studied the effect of Fe3O4 under microwave treatment. Their results showed a 20 % reduction in asphaltene content and a decrease in resin concentration from 30 to 19.4 %, attributed to the cleavage of carbon-heteroatom bonds and the enhanced energy absorption properties of magnetite. Moreover, Hanyong et al. [19] evaluated the catalytic performance of Ni-Fe bimetallic graphene-supported systems (ratios 1:0, 1:2, and 0:1) for viscosity reduction in extra-heavy oil. The 1:2 Ni-Fe catalyst produced the best results, achieving a 42.38 % viscosity reduction, which increased to 71.43 % in the presence of decalin, along with an 8.4 % decrease in heavy fraction content. Finally, Torkaman et al. [20] reported that Fe-Mn nanocatalysts (0.5 wt %, 400 W, 4 min) reduced the viscosity of heavy crude oil by 53 % and decreased sulfoxide groups by 72 %. Compared to conventional upgrading processes, such as hydrotreating, catalytic cracking, or thermal conversion, which often require high temperatures (>300 °C), extended reaction times, and pressurized hydrogen, microwave-assisted systems offer a cleaner and faster alternative [9]. However, the effectiveness of microwave irradiation depends strongly on the dielectric properties of the catalyst and its ability to interact selectively with electromagnetic fields. In this regard, biochar materials have emerged as promising microwave-absorbing supports due to their tunable surface chemistry, conductivity, and porosity [21]. When modified with transition metals such as Fe, biochars not only exhibit improved microwave absorption via interfacial polarization but also gain catalytic functionality, promoting the production of lighter and more valuable fractions [22,23]. These functionalities arise from redox-active sites and Brønsted-like acid groups [24,25]. For example, Fe-O and SO4 2- species can enhance hydrogen transfer reactions and facilitate bond cleavage under moderate thermal conditions [26]. These multifunctional properties enable biochar microspheres to serve as both microwave absorbers and active catalysts, favoring depolymerization, ring-opening, and selective cracking of heavy oil fractions. This study positions biochar microspheres as a sustainable and efficient platform for the rapid, low-temperature upgrading of heavy feedstocks by combining rational material design with microwave-responsive catalysis. Operating under remarkably mild conditions (80 °C, 6 min, and 800 W) and without pressurized hydrogen, our system offers a distinct advantage over conventional technologies that require more severe thermal and operational conditions. We investigated the influence of synthesis time and Fe impregnation on the structural and surface properties of biochar microspheres and their performance in the catalytic upgrading of VGO- FCC feedstock under microwave irradiation. Pristine and Fe-modified microspheres were synthesized via hydrothermal carbonization using starch, followed by Fe precursor impregnation, and evaluated in the presence and absence of a hydrogen donor. Our findings demonstrate that Fe incorporation and longer synthesis time enhance surface oxidation, amphiphilic balance, and dielectric behavior, resulting in substantial viscosity reduction and the conversion of heavy fractions into lighter, more valuable products. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents Starch in solution (99 %) was obtained from Bioquigen, while ammonium iron(II) sulfate hexahydrate (ACS reagent, ≥99 %) and decahydronaphthalene (a mixture of cis and trans isomers, reagent grade, 98 %) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Solvents and acids including n-heptane (≥99.3 %), acetone (ACS reagent, ≥99.5 %), toluene (≥99.8 %), decalin (98 %), nitric acid (≥65 %), and hydrochloric acid (ACS reagent, 37 %) were also acquired from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. Attapulgite (Cimsil G30, 200-mesh sieve) was provided by AlfaQuímicos S.A.S. (Bogotá, Colombia). 2.2 Synthesis of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres To synthesize biochar microspheres (BM), a 16 wt. % aqueous suspension of starch was placed in a high-pressure Teflon-lined minireactor, stirred vigorously for 30 min, and then subjected to hydrothermal treatment at 200 °C for either 6 or 12 h. After filtration, the solid was washed with a 1:1 in volume water/ethanol solution and dried at 90 °C for 24 h [27,28]. Subsequently, the BM were impregnated to incipient wetness using a 1.8 wt. % aqueous solution of Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2·6H2O at 60 °C for 2 h [29]. The obtained solid was subsequently dried at 90 °C for 24 hours. BM6 and BM12 refer to the biochar microspheres prepared at different hydrothermal treatment times, whereas FeBM6 and FeBM12 denote their respective Fe-modified counterparts. 2.3 Physicochemical characterization 2.3.1 Metal loading The metal content in Fe-modified biochar microspheres was determined by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES). Prior to analysis, the samples were ground, calcined at 500 °C for 3 h, and digested in a HNO3/HCl mixture using a MILESTONE START D microwave system. The resulting solutions were filtered, diluted with deionized water, and analyzed using a PerkinElmer OPTIMA 7300 DV spectrometer. 2.3.2 Morphology and elemental distribution Pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres were examined using a TESCAN LYRA3 Field-Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FE-SEM) with an Oxford Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) detector. The system was operated at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV and a working distance of 9 mm. 2.3.3 Powder X-ray diffraction XRD analysis was performed using a Malvern Panalytical Empyrean diffractometer with Bragg-Brentano geometry and CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Data were collected with a step size of 0.02° and a counting time of 2000 s per step. 2.3.4 Raman and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopies Raman spectra were acquired using a micro-Raman spectrometer (NT-MDT, NTEGRA SPECTRA) with a 473 nm laser, 100 × objective, and a 1 µm2 laser spot size, while FTIR spectra were collected using a Nicolet Summit LITE spectrophotometer to identify surface functional groups. All measurements were conducted at room temperature. 2.3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS analyses were conducted using a SPECS Phoibos 150 operated at 300 W and 10-9 torr, with a collection angle of 90° relative to the analyzer and the sample surface. The X-ray source was a monochromatic Al-Kα (1486.7 eV). The C 1s peak at 284.8 eV was used as an internal reference. Spectra were fitted using XPS-peak software with Gaussian/Lorentzian functions after Shirley background subtraction. 2.3.6 Zeta potential Measurements were performed by dispersing 5 mg of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres in 20 mL of distilled water, followed by sonication at 70 % amplitude for 15 min. The resulting suspension was divided into aliquots with pH values ranging from 2 to 12 (±0.1). Each 1 mL aliquot was analyzed using a Horiba SZ-100 nanoparticle analyzer. Reported values represent the average of five measurements, with an error below 5 %. 2.3.7 Contact angle A total of 30 mg of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres were dispersed in 20 mL of water and sonicated in pulsed mode (0.5 s on / 0.5 s off) for 5 min. A 3 µL water droplet was deposited onto a hydrophilic glass surface and measured using DROPimage Advance software. Values represent the average of 20 measurements taken within 1 min. 2.4 Microwave-assisted upgrading of FCC-derived vacuum gas oil Catalytic tests were carried out to evaluate the performance of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres during the upgrading of vacuum gas oil (VGO) derived from a Colombian FCC feedstock. The main physicochemical characteristics of fresh FCC feed are summarized in Table 1 . Reactions were conducted in an 800 W Samsung Amw831K/Xap microwave oven operating at 2450 MHz, using a batch setup consisting of a glass flask fitted with a reflux condenser as shown in Scheme 1 [14,19]. In a typical experiment, 50 g of FCC-VGO were ultrasonically homogenized with 2.5 wt. % of catalyst (sieved to 200–400 mesh, average particle size ≈ 0.056 mm) and 8 wt % of decalin as hydrogen donor, with both percentages calculated relative to the feedstock weight. The resulting mixture was then exposed to microwave irradiation for 6 min. The reaction temperature was monitored in real time using an infrared thermometer, reaching a maximum of 80 °C. This controlled heating minimized thermal gradients and prevented the formation of hot spots or thermal degradation [30]. A single microwave power setting (800 W) was employed, as the efficiency of microwave activation depends primarily on electromagnetic properties of the material rather than on absolute power levels, e.g., Fe particle size, dielectric loss, and interfacial polarization [29]. After treatment, 50 mL of the upgraded sample were collected for viscosity measurements, which were carried out using an NDJ-9S rotational viscometer equipped with an S2 rotor, operating at a shear rate of 30 rpm and a controlled temperature of 25 °C. Furthermore, to assess compositional changes in the upgraded oil, SARA analysis (SARA = S aturates, A romatics, R esins, A sphaltenes) was performed following ASTM D2007–19 and ASTM D3279–19, as follows: treated samples were mixed with n-heptane (1:10 v/v) and refluxed at 60 °C for 30 min to precipitate asphaltenes. The resulting mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was passed sequentially through attapulgite and silica gel columns. Saturates were eluted with n-heptane, while the resins were extracted using a toluene/acetone (1:1) mixture through the attapulgite phase, and aromatics were recovered from the silica gel using Soxhlet extraction with toluene. All experiments were performed in triplicate to ensure good reproducibility. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical characterization of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres 3.1.1 Elemental analysis The Fe content was intentionally fixed at 1.8 wt % to maximize metal dispersion while avoiding pore blockage or sintering at higher loadings (>2 wt %), which is particularly relevant for these low-porosity spherical materials, where excessive loading could compromise surface accessibility [26]. This level also preserves the structural integrity and surface functionality of the biochar support under microwave conditions [29,31,32]. Table 2 presents the elemental composition determined by ICP-OES, showing minimal deviation between the theoretical and experimental Fe concentrations, indicating effective control over the Fe loading process. XPS analysis revealed higher Fe and S concentrations compared to EDS (3.9–4.9 wt % Fe and 3.3–3.5 wt % S vs. 0.5–0.6 wt % Fe and 0.6–0.7 wt % S), indicating that Fe and S species are not deeply embedded but rather concentrated near the outermost surface. This is likely due to heterogeneous anchoring during the impregnation and drying steps and supports the presence of finely dispersed, surface-accessible Fe species. The discrepancy between EDS and XPS results further suggests that Fe is not forming large aggregates but is well distributed over the support surface. Additionally, the pristine samples (BM6 and BM12) showed only C and O signals, as expected, serving as reference point to confirm the successful incorporation of Fe and S in the FeBMx catalysts. 3.1.2 Morphology and elemental distribution Fig. 1 shows SEM images and the corresponding EDS elemental maps of the pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres. All samples consist of spherical particles with diameters predominantly in the range of 1 to 5 μm, forming loosely packed aggregates. A slight increase in average particle size was observed with longer hydrothermal treatment times, suggesting that extended synthesis promotes microsphere growth and coalescence. Elemental mapping of BM6 and BM12 confirms a homogeneous distribution of C and O, indicative of a consistent composition throughout the pristine biochar supports. In contrast, FeBM6 and FeBM12 exhibit additional signals corresponding to Fe and S, introduced via impregnation with Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2·6H2O. These elements appear uniformly distributed across the C/O matrix, indicating effective dispersion of the impregnated species. Although EDS mapping generally revealed homogeneous distribution, localized regions of higher Fe and S intensity were also observed, suggesting minor zones of inhomogeneous accumulation. This may result from partial migration or clustering of Fe-containing species within interstitial regions of the microsphere aggregates. The co-localization of Fe and S supports the possible formation of Fe-S surface complexes stabilized within the porous carbon framework. 3.1.3 Structural and local order Fig. 2 a shows the powder XRD patterns of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres. All samples exhibit a broad diffraction peak between 2θ = 5 and 30° characteristic of disordered or amorphous carbonaceous materials. This peak corresponds to the (002) plane, associated with partially graphitized aromatic domains, suggesting a certain degree of structural ordering within the carbon matrix. The intensity of this amorphous peak is notably higher in the pristine samples compared to their Fe-modified counterparts, indicating that Fe incorporation disrupts the local stacking of aromatic sheets and increases structural disorder. Additionally, the appearance of sharper and well-defined peaks at 2θ = 9.0, 9.5, 10.5, 13.9, 15.7, and 19.5°, along with a less intense peak, observed in both FeBM6 and FeBM12, confirms the presence of Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2·6H2O, as identified by JCPDS card number 01–071–2154 [33]. Fig. 2b displays the Raman spectra of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres. All samples exhibit the two characteristic vibrational bands of carbon-based materials: the D band (1369- 1385 cm-1), associated with structural defects in sp2-hybridized carbon, and the G band (1591–1594 cm-1), attributed to the stretching of in-plane CC bonds in graphitic domains [34–36]. The intensity ratio (D/G) serves as a semi-quantitative indicator of structural disorder within the carbon framework [35,37]. BM6 exhibits the highest D/G ratio (2.09), indicating a higher degree of disorder and a less graphitized structure. This is consistent with its shorter hydrothermal treatment time, which limits aromatic reorganization. In contrast, BM12 shows a lower D/G ratio (1.86), suggesting improved ordering due to prolonged synthesis. These trends correlate well with the XRD results (Fig. 2a), where BM12 exhibits a more defined (002) peak than BM6, confirming a higher degree of structural organization. This behavior aligns with the model reported by Ferrari and Robertson [38], which relates higher D/G values to smaller graphitic domains and increased disorder [37,38]. On the other hand, the Fe-modified samples, FeBM6 and FeBM12, exhibit D/G ratios of 1.87 and 1.89, respectively, both lower than BM6 and comparable to BM12, suggesting that Fe incorporation does not introduce additional disorder. On the contrary, Fe may promote local graphitization by acting as a catalytic agent during thermal treatment, as reported in studies on Fe-assisted graphitization of biomass-derived carbons [39]. 3.1.4 Molecular structure Fig. 3 shows the FTIR spectra of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres. All samples exhibit multiple absorption bands corresponding to characteristic functional groups on the carbon surface. The peaks at 2981 and 2888 cm-1 are assigned to asymmetric and symmetric CH stretching modes of -CH3 and -CH2- groups, respectively, indicating the presence of aliphatic structures likely resulting from the partial decomposition of starch during hydrothermal carbonization [40]. The band near 1694 cm-1 is attributed to C=O stretching, while the signal around 1595 cm-1 corresponds to C=C skeletal vibrations, confirming the presence of aromatic domains. Additional peaks at 1385, 1247, 1158, and 952 cm-1 are associated with CH bending, aromatic CO stretching, CO-H bending, and skeletal vibrations of polysaccharide-like structures, respectively, consistent with residual cellulose or hemicellulose components from the carbon precursor [40–42]. Notably, differences are observed between the pristine and Fe-modified samples. In FeBM6 and FeBM12, a pronounced band emerges at approximately 1070 cm-1, corresponding to S-O stretching vibrations, while a weak shoulder in the 590–600 cm-1 region is attributed to Fe-O bond stretching from the precursor. 3.1.5 Surface elemental states XPS analysis was performed to assess the surface composition and chemical states of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres. Peak assignments were made by comparison with reference values from the NIST XPS database [43]. Table 3 summarizes the surface concentrations of C, O, Fe, and S species, while Fig. 4 presents the corresponding deconvoluted high-resolution spectra. Fig. 4a shows the high-resolution C1s XPS spectra and corresponding peak deconvolution of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres. The main surface functionalities identified include graphitic carbon at 284.6 eV; CO bonds from ether or phenolic groups (286.1–286.3 eV); C=O from carbonyl or quinone groups (287.3–287.6 eV); OC=O from carboxylic or ester functionalities (288.4–288.9 eV); and the characteristic π-π* satellite (290.4–290.8 eV) [43–45]. The pristine samples exhibit a dominant contribution from graphitic carbon (56.8–58.3 %), indicative of a surface enriched in sp2-hybridized domains and low degree of oxidation. The presence of oxygen-containing species is limited to CO (7.1–8.1 %) and C=O (3.2–3.9 %), with no detectable signals corresponding to OC=O functionalities. The moderate intensity of the π-π* satellite (1.0 %) further supports the existence of delocalized aromatic structures [46]. In contrast, the graphitic carbon content in FeBM6 and FeBM12 decreases markedly to 37.9 and 29.6 %, respectively, while the relative contributions of CO (4.7 and 9.7 %) and C=O (5.5 and 6.8 %) species become more pronounced. Additionally, new contributions from OC=O groups emerge (3.6–4.6 %). These transformations are consistent with previous reports on the modification of carbonaceous materials through transition metal incorporation [47]. Notably, the intensity of the π-π* satellite decreases to 0.4 and 0.8, respectively, suggesting a diminished extent of aromatic conjugation. These changes reflect the significant impact of Fe-based chemical treatment on the carbon bonding environment and confirm the formation of more oxygen-rich, functionally diverse surface states in the modified materials. Fig. 4b displays the high-resolution O1s spectra of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres, showing distinct peak at low (529.6–529.8 eV), intermediate (531.4–531.7 eV), and high (533.0–533.6 eV) binding energies [48].The low-energy peak, typically attributed to oxygen bound to metal centers such as Fe-O, is clearly present in all samples, including the unmodified ones. Its intensities, 1.8 % in BM6 and BM12 and increased values of 3.4 % in FeBM6 and 4.9 % in FeBM12, suggest that, in the pristine samples, this signal likely originates from conjugated carbonyl species (CCS), such as quinones or lactones embedded within the graphitic matrix [49]. In the Fe-impregned samples, the increased intensity of the low-energy peak confirms the partial formation of Fe-O species as a result of interaction with the Fe-precursor. The dominant signal in all cases appears at intermediate binding energies and is attributed to C=O functionalities, such as ketones, lactones, or anhydrides. This component accounts for 17.7 % in BM6 and 18.3 % in BM12, but increases to 21.3 and 18.9 % in FeBM6 and FeBM12, respectively, supporting the occurrence of surface oxidation and the redistribution of oxygen species. Finally, the high-energy peak, assigned to C-O-H and C-O-C groups, increases upon Fe doping from 10.7 to 10.3 % in BM6 and BM12 to 16.0 and 16.3 % in FeBM6 and FeBM12, respectively. These results, consistent with the C1s spectra, confirm that Fe doping promotes surface oxidation, leading to the formation of more polar oxygen-containing functionalities, particularly in FeBM12. Fig. 4c shows the high-resolution Fe2p XPS spectra of Fe-modified biochar microspheres, confirming the presence of Fe species. The Fe2p3/2 peaks appear at 710.6 eV for FeBM6 and 711.2 eV for FeBM12, accompanied by their respective Fe2p1/2 signal between 713.7 and 714.5 eV. The main Fe2p3/2 peak in FeBM6 aligns well with the characteristic binding energy of Fe2+ in FeSO4, whereas the slight shift toward higher binding energy observed in FeBM12 suggests a partially oxidized or hydrated state [43,50,51]. This variation is likely due to subtle differences in local coordination environments or partial exposure to ambient moisture, phenomena commonly reported for Fe-impregnated carbonaceous materials [51,52]. In parallel, the S2p spectra corroborates the formation of Fe-sulfate species on the surface of the Fe-modified samples. Both FeBM6 and FeBM12 exhibit well-resolved S2p doublets attributable to sulfate anions (SO4 2-) and Fe-bound sulfate, with binding energies consistent with values reported in the literature [51,52]. Quantitatively, FeBM12 displays a slightly higher proportion of FeSO4 compared to FeBM6, as well as a marginally greater fraction of free SO4 2-, suggesting stronger Fe2+-support interactions with longer synthesis times. This trend is consistent with the O1s and C1s data, which show higher proportions of carbonyl-type oxygen groups in FeBM12 (18.9 % and 6.8 %, respectively) than in FeBM6 (21.3 % and 5.5 %), favoring Fe coordination. These results indicate that extended hydrothermal treatment enhances the effective anchoring of Fe-sulfate species and potentially contributes to improved catalytic performance through the formation of stabilized Fe-S surface complexes. 3.1.6 Electrostatic properties Fig. 5 shows the zeta potential profiles of pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres. All samples exhibit negative surface charges across the entire pH range, confirming their anionic character in aqueous conditions. Notably, BM12 is the only sample that shows slightly positive zeta potential values at pH 2 and 4, indicating surface protonation under strongly acidic conditions, likely due to higher density of protonable oxygen-containing functional groups, such as -OH or -COOH, promoted by extended hydrothermal treatment. In contrast, BM6, FeBM6, and FeBM12 maintain negative zeta potential throughout the pH range, with increasing negativity as the pH rises, attributed to the progressive deprotonation of acidic surface functionalities. The absence of a charge inversion point indicates that their isoelectric points lie below pH 2. Moreover, the persistent negative charge at all pH values may also be influenced by the delocalized π-electron cloud in aromatic carbon domains. These results are consistent with previous observations reports by Wiśniewska et al. [53]. 3.1.7 Wettability and surface hydrophilicity Fig. 6 shows the contact angle of water droplets on pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres, revealing significant variations in surface wettability. The results indicate that the interaction between the biochar particles and the glass substrate influences the contact angle, reflecting changes in surface hydrophilic/hydrophobic. BM6 exhibits low contact angles (32.6–35°), indicating a highly hydrophilic surface, likely due to a high density of polar oxygen-containing functional groups. In contrast, BM12 shows substantially higher angles (58.1–65.6°), suggesting reduced surface polarity, likely resulting from the depletion of hydroxyl and carboxyl group concentration following extended hydrothermal treatment. Fe-modified samples display intermediate wettability; FeBM6 shows contact angles around 47.5°, while FeBM12 reaches up to 60.4°, suggesting that Fe incorporation decreases surface hydrophilicity, although both materials remain within the moderately wettable regime. These trends are consistent with the zeta potential measurement, which revealed less negative surface charges for BM12 and FeBM12 at acidic pH, correlating with a lower density of surface acid groups. The observed increase in contact angle with both synthesis time and Fe incorporation suggests that surface chemistry, particularly the balance between polar and aromatic domains, plays a key role in determining water affinity. 3.2 Catalytic tests The microwave-assisted upgrading of FCC-derived VGO using pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres was evaluated by analyzing the SARA fractions and viscosity, as shown in Table 4 . All catalytic systems induced compositional shifts toward lighter fractions, characterized by an increase in saturates and aromatics and a concurrent reduction in resins and asphaltenes. The untreated FCC-VGO exhibited high viscosity (444 ± 6.9 mPa·s), a dominant aromatic fraction (47.0 ± 3.1 wt %), and a relatively low content of saturates (42.1 ± 0.8 wt %), consistent with a heavy hydrocarbon matrix rich in polar fractions such as resins and asphaltenes (11.0 ± 0.8 wt %). After catalytic treatment with BM6 and BM12, the VGO composition shifted toward lighter fractions, evidenced by an increase in saturates to 63.7 ± 4.6 and 63.6 ± 4.8 wt %, a decrease in asphaltenes to 2.8 ± 0.1 and 3.2 ± 0.04 wt %, and viscosity reductions to 411 ± 31.1 and 429 ± 33.1 mPa·s, corresponding to relative decreases of 7.4 % and 3.4 %, respectively. The heavy fraction also decreased to 7.4 ± 0.2 wt % and 8.2 ± 0.3 wt %, representing reductions of 32.7 % and 25.5 % compared to the feed. Fe incorporation using Fe(NH₄)₂(SO₄)₂·6H₂O significantly enhanced catalytic performance: FeBM6 and FeBM12 reduced viscosity to 305 ± 7.1 and 330 ± 25.3 mPa·s, corresponding to relative decreases of 31.3 % and 25.7 % compared to the feed, while maintaining low asphaltene levels (2.7 ± 0.1 and 3.1 ± 0.3 wt %) and increasing saturates to 63.5 ± 2.6 and 64.0 ± 2.4 wt %. The heavy fraction was also reduced to 6.7 ± 0.1 wt % and 7.7 ± 0.4 wt %, equivalent to decreases of 39.1 % and 30.0 % relative to VGO. These catalytic effects are strongly linked to surface chemical modifications revealed by XPS [54]. Although the numerical order of saturates content, BM6-HD (65.3 ± 4.1 wt %) < BM12-HD (65.6 ± 2.9 wt %) < FeBM6-HD (66.5 ± 3.5 wt %) < FeBM12-HD (66.6 ± 2.8 wt %), may appear to suggest an increasing trend, these differences fall within the range of experimental variability and therefore cannot be regarded as statistically significant. Nevertheless, the reproducibility of these values across replicates, together with the consistent decrease in viscosity (up to 77 %) and in heavy fractions, provides a coherent picture of upgrading. Thus, while we refrain from claiming a strict monotonic increase in saturates, the modest yet reproducible compositional variations observed are coherent with the catalytic performance, reinforcing the consistency of viscosity and fractionation data. In FeBMx samples, the content of oxygenated functional groups increased substantially; carbonyl groups (C = O) rose from 3.9 % in BM6 to 5.5 % and 6.8 % in FeBM6 and FeBM12, respectively, while carboxylic groups (O–C = O), absent in the BM samples, were detected at 3.6 and 4.6 % in FeBM6 and FeBM12. Additionally, Fe–O species (3.4–4.9 %) and signals attributable to Fe²⁺, SO₄²⁻, and Fe–SO₄²⁻ (up to 2.9 % in FeBM12) were observed, indicating the presence of redox and Brønsted-like acid sites. These functionalities, associated with enhanced surface acidity and polarity, facilitate C–S and C–O bond cleavage, ring-opening reactions, and the selective breakdown of heavy components. The most significant transformations were observed for Fe-modified catalysts in the presence of a hydrogen donor (HD). The viscosity data support these observations, revealing substantial reductions in the presence of both Fe and HD. The order of viscosity decrease was BM6-HD (142 ± 8.2 mPa·s; 68.0 %) > BM12-HD (130 ± 7.6 mPa·s; 70.7 %) > FeBM6-HD (119 ± 6.9 mPa·s; 73.2 %) > FeBM12-HD (102 ± 7.4 mPa·s; 77.0 %), representing a maximum reduction of 77.0 % compared to the fresh feedstock. These changes were accompanied by further increases in saturates content in the following order: BM6-HD (65.3 ± 4.1 wt %) < BM12-HD (65.6 ± 2.9 wt %) < FeBM6-HD (66.5 ± 3.5 wt %) < FeBM12-HD (66.6 ± 2.8 wt %). Additionally, asphaltenes and resins were reduced by up to 55.3 % (2.1 ± 0.1 wt %) and 47.6 % (3.3 ± 0.2 wt %), respectively, relative to the untreated feed. These changes can be attributed to the Fe incorporation, which induces significant surface chemical transformations in the biochar microspheres [16], leading to the development of active catalytic sites that facilitate hydrogen transfer and enhance thermal desorption processes. Under mild microwave-assisted conditions, these changes the depolymerization of heavy fractions in FCC-VGO through catalytic cracking of resinous and asphaltenic macromolecules, ring-opening reactions, and heteroatom bond cleavage [18], which collectively promote the formation of more hydrogenated and less polar hydrocarbon species. On the contrary, in the absence of hydrogen donors, adverse effects such as increased viscosity were observed, attributed to uncontrolled radical-induced polymerization under microwave irradiation [14,55]. Without hydrogen quenching or active catalytic sites, reactive intermediates from resins and asphaltenes can recombine to form larger aromatic structures and high-molecular-weight species. This behavior aligns with previous studies showing that microwave treatment without hydrogen sources promotes polycondensation rather than cracking, impairing upgrading efficiency [14]. These results underscore the essential role of hydrogen donors and active catalysts in suppressing polymerization and enhancing heavy oil upgrading. A key factor in microwave-assisted catalysis is the material’s microwave absorption efficiency, typically measured by its dielectric loss tangent (tan δ). Although dielectric parameters such as permittivity or loss tangent were not directly measured in this work, several physicochemical indicators support the effective microwave absorption of FeBM12. For example, contact angle measurements (60.4° for FeBM12) indicate a moderately wettable surface, while zeta potential analysis confirms a negatively charged interface, suggesting the favorable conditions for dipolar polarization under microwave irradiation [56,57]. Additionally, XPS revealed the presence of surface carbon-oxygenated species, Fe-O bonds, and SO4 2- groups, which may contribute to interfacial polarization and dielectric loss [22]. These features, combined with the conductive carbon matrix, enable efficient localized heating. Notably, previous studies have demonstrated that microwave irradiation can significantly enhance the surface free energy of materials, such as polypropylene, thereby increasing their hydrophilicity and improving surface reactivity through oxidative and structural modifications [56]. Moreover, the observed viscosity reduction and absence of coke formation suggest that the Fe-based catalyst facilitates bond cleavage via synergistic thermal and non-thermal microwave effects. The use of Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2·6H2O as the Fe precursor played a strategic role in tailoring the catalytic surface properties. This salt not only provides Fe2+ species upon impregnation but also introduces SO4 2- groups, as confirmed by XPS. These surface Fe-O and SO4 2- functionalities contribute to the generation of redox-active Fe2+/Fe3+ pairs and Brønsted-like acid sites, both of which facilitate electron transfer for the activation and cleavage of C-S and C-O bonds under microwave conditions [58]. The combined presence of iron and sulfate enhances microwave susceptibility through interfacial polarization and facilitates localized heating, as reported in similar systems. This synergy is reflected in the observed viscosity reduction and improved catalytic performance, particularly in the FeBM12-HD system. Fig. 7 displays the FTIR spectra of FCC-VGO before and after microwave-assisted upgrading using pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres as catalysts, both with and without a hydrogen donor. In the untreated FCC-VGO, characteristic bands are observed for the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of -CH3 groups, along with additional signals attributed to -CH2 vibrations. Bands near 1664, 1099, and 650 cm-1 are also present, corresponding to C=C, S-CH3, and S-C bonds, respectively. Notable changes in these functional groups are evident after catalytic microwave treatment. A relative decrease in the -CH2 band and an increase in -CH3 intensity is observed in all upgraded samples, particularly for FeBM12. This trend is indicative of dealkylation reactions and suggests fragmentation of long aliphatic chains into shorter alkyl groups, as expected during efficient hydroprocessing under reducing conditions [14]. The FTIR spectra are overall very similar across catalysts, with only subtle variations. The most evident distinction is observed between BM12 and FeBM12, although these spectra still resemble each other closely. Catalysts synthesized for shorter times (BM6 and FeBM6) show negligible contributions from S–CH₃ and C–S bands (∼1000–1100 and 650 cm⁻¹), whereas longer synthesis (BM12 and FeBM12) leads to more noticeable features in this region, consistent with residual sulfur-containing compounds. Importantly, the use of a hydrogen donor results in a marked attenuation of these bands (Fig. 7a), particularly in FeBM12, suggesting effective cleavage of sulfur–carbon bonds. By contrast, without hydrogen donor the BM12 and FeBM12 spectra exhibit more intense S–CH₃ and C–S signals, in line with repolymerization or recombination of sulfur fragments [17,59]. Although FTIR provides qualitative information, these reproducible patterns are in agreement with the observed viscosity reduction and decrease in heavy fractions, reinforcing the catalytic trends. Furthermore, spectral changes in the 1455 and 1376 cm⁻¹ regions, corresponding to -CH2 and -CH3 bending vibrations, indicate a higher relative abundance of alkyl groups in the upgraded samples. This is accompanied by a decline in the aromatic C=C stretching band at 1607 cm-1, suggesting partial hydrogenation or ring-opening of aromatic structures. These shifts are more pronounced in Fe-modified systems, particularly FeBM12, revealing its superior catalytic ability to break down condensed aromatics and promote hydrocarbon chain remodeling. These spectroscopic trends confirm that microwave-assisted upgrading in the presence of Fe-based catalysts and a hydrogen donor promotes dealkylation, desulfurization, and the conversion of high-molecular-weight aromatics into lighter aliphatic species. These findings are fully consistent with the SARA and viscosity results, which showed increased saturates and aromatics, and a substantial decrease in resins and asphaltenes, especially under FeBM12-HD conditions. In the microwave-assisted upgrading of heavy oils, we developed an efficient catalytic system based on Fe-modified, biomass-derived microspheres (FeBMx) using decalin as a hydrogen donor. This system achieved a 77.03 % reduction in viscosity within just 6 min at temperatures below 80 °C, without requiring external hydrogen or additional organic solvents. The treated VGO exhibited a marked increase in saturates (65.63 wt %) and substantial reductions in asphaltenes (52.98 %) and resins (22.2 %), indicating effective conversion of heavy fractions into lighter, more valuable components. Comprehensive characterization confirmed that catalytic performance is enhanced by the uniform dispersion of Fe species and the presence of amphiphilic surface functionalities. These features facilitate microwave absorption, promote hydrogen transfer, and stabilize reactive intermediates, thereby suppressing undesirable polymerization pathways. Additionally, the catalyst exhibits excellent colloidal stability (-30.7 mV) and a balanced hydrophilic-hydrophobic character (contact angle: 60.4°), which favors an uniform dispersion in the VGO matrix, improving interfacial contact and enabling efficient hydrogen transfer and bond cleavage during microwave-assisted upgrading [60,61]. XPS analysis confirmed the presence of Fe-O and SO₄²⁻ surface species in Fe-modified catalysts. Although these features do not directly evidence catalytic performance, their identification is crucial for understanding the structural environment and establishing correlations with the observed behavior. Compared to similar Fe–biochar catalysts reported in the literature, the catalytic mechanism of the present system is distinct due to the coexistence of surface sulfate functionalities and the enhanced response to microwave energy [29]. While conventional systems often rely on basic carbon surfaces and classical Fe2+/Fe3+ redox activity, the presence of SO4 2- groups introduces Brønsted acidity, which, in combination with polar Fe-O bonds, promotes polarization and activation of C-S and C-O bonds [26]. This dual mechanism, combining acid catalysis and microwave-assisted electron transfer, provides a structural rationale for the viscosity reduction and compositional shifts observed, helping to explain the efficiency of Fe-modified catalysts under microwave conditions. Additionally, as summarized in Table 5 , our system is comparably effective but significantly more energy-efficient, operating at lower temperatures and shorter duration (80 °C and 6 min) than other microwave-assisted catalytic systems (typically 260 °C and 20 min). For instance, Hanyong et al. [19] reported a 71.43 % viscosity reduction using a Ni-Fe/graphene catalyst with decalin, but their system required additional chemicals and complex nanomaterials, increasing both operational and environmental costs. Similarly, Adam et al. [62] required microwave temperatures up to 425 °C to reduce viscosity below 100 cP, relying on commercial HDS catalysts, which limits energy efficiency and scalability. Vakhin et al. [18] and Lu et al. [65] reported moderate viscosity reductions (40–42 %) using Fe3O4 nanoparticles, while Farshadfar et al. [66] achieved 42 % reduction and a 4.47° API increase using Fe3O4-NiO catalysts, though their studies lacked detailed surface analysis. On the other hand, Dehaghani and Saeedi [67] and Taheri et al. [15,16] reported only modest improvements (10–15 %) using acidic solutions and nanoparticles, attributing the changes to modified surface polarity and microwave absorption, but without in-depth structural insights. Zhang et al. [68] achieved a 90 % viscosity reduction, but under extreme conditions (440 °C, 30 min). Li et al. [14] presented a notable early example of carbon-based nanocatalysis, reporting >96 % viscosity reduction at 150 °C with 21 nm carbon particles. However, their performance dropped drastically with larger particle sizes (5 % with 50 µm) and suffered from viscosity regression after 20 days. Moreover, no surface characterization was provided, limiting reproducibility. It is important to note that conventional FCC catalysts were not used for comparison due to their low dielectric loss (tan δ < 0.1) [22,69], which limits their efficiency under microwave irradiation. In contrast, FeBM12 exhibits enhanced dielectric properties derived from the synergistic combination of conductive biochar and Fe-based species, enabling efficient localized heating. These findings underscore the importance of incorporating microwave-susceptible components into catalyst design, especially for low-severity heavy oil upgrading processes where traditional FCC materials may underperform. To further evaluate the sustainability of both the catalyst and the support, a recyclability test was performed over three consecutive cycles. After each reaction, the solid catalyst was recovered by centrifugation, thoroughly washed with acetone, dried at 80 °C, and reused under identical conditions with fresh heavy crude oil. The viscosity measurements (Table 4) demonstrated consistent performance across all catalyst systems, with FeBM12-HD showing the lowest viscosity values (102. 107, and 110 mPa·s) and variations below 5 % between cycles, indicating excellent catalytic stability and reusability. Similarly, FeBM6-HD and BM12-HD maintained good performance, although with slightly higher viscosities than FeBM12-HD. These results confirm the chemical and structural stability of the catalyst, reinforcing its potential as a reusable and sustainable material for heavy oil upgrading applications. These results confirm that FeBM12-HD exhibited the best performance in reducing viscosity (77.03 %) and increasing the saturate content, under mild microwave conditions. To contextualize these findings, a comparative analysis with previous catalytic systems is presented in Table 5. Unlike other catalysts that operate at elevated temperatures (e.g., 260–425 °C), require complex supports (e.g. graphene), or show limited effectiveness (10–53 % viscosity reduction), FeBM12-HD achieves superior upgrading efficiency at just 80 °C and 6 mins the need for pressurized hydrogen. Furthermore, it avoids common drawbacks such as viscosity rebound, poor surface reactivity, or limited microwave absorption. This performance is attributed to the enhanced amphiphilic balance, surface oxidation, and interfacial polarization of the Fe-biochar, making it a highly effective and sustainable option for heavy oil upgrading. 4 Conclusions The microwave-assisted upgrading of FCC-derived VGO employing pristine and Fe-modified biochar microspheres synthesized via hydrothermal carbonization of starch demonstrated that both synthesis time and Fe incorporation play a critical role in tuning catalytic performance. Among the catalysts, the FeBM12–HD system exhibited the most effective transformation of heavy fractions, achieving a 77.0 % viscosity reduction (from 444 ± 6.9 to 102 ± 7.4 mPa·s), modest but reproducible increases in saturates (66.6 ± 2.8 wt %), and a reduction in asphaltenes to 2.1 ± 0.1 wt % under mild microwave conditions (80 °C, 6 min, 800 W) in the presence of decalin as hydrogen donor. While the differences in saturates are within experimental variability and not statistically significant, their reproducibility and alignment with viscosity and fractionation trends indicate a consistent upgrading effect. The improved performance of FeBM12 was attributed to synergistic effects between extended synthesis time, homogeneous Fe dispersion, and enhanced surface functionalization. FTIR spectra were largely similar across catalysts, yet qualitative distinctions such as the attenuation of S–CH₃ and C–S bands in the presence of a hydrogen donor were observed, consistent with C–S bond cleavage. XPS analysis revealed Fe–O and SO₄²⁻ species that, although not direct evidence of catalytic activity, provide structural context and support correlations with the observed performance. SEM images verified the formation of well-defined spherical morphologies, while contact angle and zeta potential measurements revealed improved colloidal stability and favorable oil–catalyst interfacial behavior. These physicochemical characteristics facilitated enhanced microwave absorption, efficient cleavage of C-S and C-O bonds, and effective desorption of heavy components. Additionally, the formation of FeSO4-like phases, preservation of graphitic domains, and strong metal-carbon interactions further contributed to catalytic activity. Therefore, FeBM12 emerges as a promising low-impact catalyst, combining biomass-derived carbon, mild synthesis, and efficient microwave activation. Its reusability, low-temperature operation, and reduced environmental footprint support its potential for sustainable refining strategies, while acknowledging that future studies with higher-resolution product profiling would further validate and extend these findings. coredata.dc:description: Fe-modified biochar microspheres (FeBM) were developed as sustainable catalysts for the microwave-assisted upgrading of Fluid Catalytic Cracking-derived Vacuum Gas Oil (FCC-VGO), both in the presence and absence of decaline as hydrogen donor source. The biochars were synthesized by hydrothermal carbonization of starch at 200 °C for 6 and 12 h, followed by incipient wetness impregnation with 1.8 wt% Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2·6H2O. Structural and surface analyses (FTIR, XPS, Raman, SEM) confirmed the formation of carbonaceous microspheres with homogeneously dispersed Fe species, surface oxidation (Fe-O, SO4 2-), and stability under microwave irradiation. These features enhanced interfacial polarization and amphiphilic balance, facilitating the cleavage of S-C and aromatic CO bonds. Raman spectra confirmed the preservation of carbon domains after Fe incorporation. Under mild conditions (80 °C, 6 min, 800 W), FeBM12 exhibited the best catalytic performance, achieving a 77.03% viscosity reduction (from 444 to 102 mPa·s), increasing saturates to 65.6 wt%, and reducing asphaltenes to 2.2 wt%. Zeta potential measurements (-30.7 mV for FeBM12) and contact angle analysis (60.4°) demonstrated enhanced colloidal stability and surface polarity. These parameters favored catalyst dispersion and oil-catalyst interactions, which are critical for microwave responsiveness and catalytic efficiency. In comparison to conventional systems requiring high temperatures, long reaction times, or pressurized hydrogen, FeBM12 offers a low-cost, low-temperature, and energy-efficient platform for upgrading FCC-derived VGO.
